org.jnativehook

Class GlobalScreen

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.jnativehook.GlobalScreen

  • public class GlobalScreen
extends Object
    GlobalScreen is used to represent the native screen area that Java does not usually have access to. This class can be thought of as the source component for native input events.

    This class also handles the loading, unpacking and communication with the native library. That includes registering and un-registering the native hook with the underlying operating system and adding global keyboard and mouse listeners.

    Version:
    1.1
    Author:
    Alexander Barker (alex@1stleg.com)

      • finalize

        protected void finalize()
                 throws Throwable
        A destructor that will perform native cleanup by calling the unregisterNativeHook() method. This method will not run until the class is garbage collected.
        Overrides:
        finalize in class Object
        Throws:
        Throwable - a NativeHookException raised by calling unloadNativeLibrary()
        See Also:
        Object.finalize()

      • addNativeKeyListener

        public void addNativeKeyListener(NativeKeyListener listener)
        Adds the specified native key listener to receive key events from the native system. If listener is null, no exception is thrown and no action is performed.
        Parameters:
        listener - a native key listener object

      • removeNativeKeyListener

        public void removeNativeKeyListener(NativeKeyListener listener)
        Removes the specified native key listener so that it no longer receives key events from the native system. This method performs no function if the listener specified by the argument was not previously added. If listener is null, no exception is thrown and no action is performed.
        Parameters:
        listener - a native key listener object

      • registerNativeHook

        public static void registerNativeHook()
                               throws NativeHookException
        Enable the native hook if it is not currently running. If it is running the function has no effect.

        Note: This method will throw a NativeHookException if specific operating system features are unavailable or disabled. For example: Access for assistive devices is unchecked in the Universal Access section of the System Preferences on Apple's OS X platform or Load "record" is missing for the xorg.conf file on Unix/Linux/Solaris platforms.

        Throws:
        NativeHookException - problem registering the native hook with the underlying operating system.
        Since:
        1.1

      • unregisterNativeHook

        public static void unregisterNativeHook()
        Disable the native hook if it is currently registered. If the native hook it is not registered the function has no effect.
        Since:
        1.1

      • isNativeHookRegistered

        public static boolean isNativeHookRegistered()
        Returns true if the native hook is currently registered.
        Returns:
        true if the native hook is currently registered.
        Throws:
        NativeHookException - the native hook exception
        Since:
        1.1

      • postNativeEvent

        public static void postNativeEvent(NativeInputEvent e)
        Send a native input event to the system.
        Since:
        1.2

      • dispatchEvent

        public final void dispatchEvent(NativeInputEvent e)
        Dispatches an event to the appropriate processor. This method is generally called by the native library but maybe used to synthesize native events from Java.

        Note: This method executes on the native systems event queue. It is imperative that all processing be off-loaded to other threads. Failure to do so may result in the delay of user input and the automatic removal of the native hook.

      • setEventDispatcher

        public final void setEventDispatcher(ExecutorService dispatcher)
        Set a different executor service for native event delivery. By default, JNativeHook utilizes a single thread executor to dispatch events from the native event queue. You may choose to use an alternative approach for event delivery by implementing an ExecutorService.

        Note: Using null as an ExecutorService will cause all delivered events to be discard until a valid ExecutorService is set.

        Parameters:
        dispatcher - The ExecutorService used to dispatch native events.
        Since:
        1.2
        See Also:
        ExecutorService, Executors.newSingleThreadExecutor()
